articles.headline: Democrats Put Cultural Issues in Their Quiver
articles.snippet: Democrats are using wedge issues in states like Virginia, North Carolina and Colorado to stoke concerns about Republicans among moderate voters, especially women.
articles.abstract: Democrats are using wedge issues in states like Virginia, North Carolina and Colorado to stoke concerns about Republicans among moderate voters, especially women.
articles.lead_paragraph: RESTON, Va. — After a generation of campaigns in which Republicans exploited wedge issues to win close elections, Democrats are now on the offensive in the culture wars.

articles.headline: ISIS Draws a Steady Stream of Recruits From Turkey
articles.snippet: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.
articles.abstract: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Having spent most of his youth as a drug addict in one of the poorest neighborhoods of Turkey’s capital, Can did not think he had much to lose when he was smuggled into Syria with 10 of his childhood friends to join the world’s most extreme jihadist group.

articles.headline: U.S. to Commit Up to 3,000 Troops to Fight Ebola in Africa
articles.snippet: Under pressure to do more to confront the Ebola outbreak sweeping across West Africa, President Obama is expanding military and medical resources to combat the spread of the deadly virus.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to do more to confront the Ebola outbreak sweeping across West Africa, President Obama is expanding military and medical resources to combat the spread of the deadly virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to do more to confront the Ebola outbreak sweeping across West Africa, President Obama on Tuesday is to announce an expansion of military and medical resources to combat the spread of the deadly virus, administration officials said.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Michael D. Shear and Denise Grady

articles.headline: As Bond-Buying Ends, Yellen Now Will Chart Course for Federal Reserve
articles.snippet: The Fed will next need to focus on the central bank’s power to set interest rates, but economic and strategic questions will shape their decisions.
articles.abstract: The Fed will next need to focus on the central bank’s power to set interest rates, but economic and strategic questions will shape their decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve’s chairwoman, the easy part is over. The first phase of the Fed’s retreat from its economic stimulus campaign, plotted by her predecessor, is nearly complete. Now, as Ms. Yellen nears the end of her first year in office, it is her turn to chart the way forward.

articles.headline: SABMiller’s Bid for Heineken Opens the Door to Possible Beer Industry Mergers
articles.snippet: The bid by the second-largest beer company in the world fueled speculation of deals on the horizon, but closing them may not be so easy.
articles.abstract: The bid by the second-largest beer company in the world fueled speculation of deals on the horizon, but closing them may not be so easy.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Anheuser-Busch InBev moved to take full control of the Mexican beer maker Modelo, it thought the deal would be a cinch.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Atlanta Hawks’ Owner Stumbles on Line Between Business and Bias
articles.snippet: After outrage over an email by Bruce Levenson, corporate leaders have begun a conversation about singling out demographic groups in marketing and the language used to do it.
articles.abstract: After outrage over an email by Bruce Levenson, corporate leaders have begun a conversation about singling out demographic groups in marketing and the language used to do it.
articles.lead_paragraph: “My theory is that the black crowd scared away the whites and there are simply not enough affluent black fans to build a significant season ticket base.”

articles.headline: For James Foley’s Family, U.S. Policy Offered No Hope
articles.snippet: After Mr. Foley was kidnapped by ISIS, the government offered sympathy but little active support, his family said, leaving them overwhelmed and unsure of what to do.
articles.abstract: After Mr. Foley was kidnapped by ISIS, the government offered sympathy but little active support, his family said, leaving them overwhelmed and unsure of what to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: The email appeared in Michael Foley’s inbox a year after his brother James disappeared on a reporting trip in northern Syria. It made clear that the people holding him wanted one thing above all else: money.

articles.headline: Hollywood’s Old-Time Star Makers Are Swooping In on YouTube’s Party
articles.snippet: The star-making system of the future, it turns out, needs the star-making system of the past — or at least a swarm of agents and managers has decided it does.
articles.abstract: The star-making system of the future, it turns out, needs the star-making system of the past — or at least a swarm of agents and managers has decided it does.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A few months ago, CBS Films wanted Bethany Mota, an 18-year-old video blogger, to make a cameo appearance in the movie “The Duff” and tell her 7.2 million YouTube followers about the experience. CBS figured that Ms. Mota, known for making fashion videos from her Los Banos, Calif., bedroom, would jump at the chance.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Hunter Atkins

articles.headline: In Kentucky, Health Law Helps Voters but Saps Votes
articles.snippet: Although expanded coverage made the state an early success story, there is little evidence it will help Democrats there in the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Although expanded coverage made the state an early success story, there is little evidence it will help Democrats there in the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Affordable Care Act allowed Robin Evans, an eBay warehouse packer earning $9 an hour, to sign up for Medicaid this year. She is being treated for high blood pressure and Graves’ disease, an autoimmune disorder, after years of going uninsured and rarely seeing doctors.

articles.headline: U.S. General Open to Ground Forces in Fight Against ISIS in Iraq
articles.snippet: Remarks by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, open the door to a riskier, more expansive American combat role than the president has publicly outlined.
articles.abstract: Remarks by Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, open the door to a riskier, more expansive American combat role than the president has publicly outlined.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s top military adviser said Tuesday that he would recommend deploying United States forces in ground operations against Islamic extremists in Iraq if airstrikes proved insufficient, opening the door to a riskier, more expansive American combat role than the president has publicly outlined.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jeremy W. Peters
